description: By character class By character class ing rocks.A lesser cyclops can hurl rocks weighing 40 to 50 pounds each (Small objects), and a greater cyclops can hurl rocks of 60 to 80 pounds (Medium-size objects). Both varieties’ rocks have a range increment of 140 feet and a maximum range of five range increments. Rock Catching (Ex): A cyclops can catch Small, Medium-size, or Large rocks (or projectiles of similar shape). Once per round, a cyclops that would normally be hit by a rock can make a Reflex save to catch it. The DC is 15 for a Small rock, 20 for a Medium-size one, and 25 for a Large one. (If the projectile has a magi- cal bonus on attacks, the DC increases by that amount.) The giant must be ready for and aware of the attack. FAUN Medium-Size Fey

description: Underneath and beyond the tremen- dous Mountains of the West, the Offering Fields offer peace and prosperity to the souls of the righteous. Seven enormous gates provide passage to the Seven Halls, each one of which is a cavern large enough to hold several cities. Each of the Seven Halls con- tains prosperous farms and estates, the reward of the righteous dead. Deeper under the mountains beyond the Seven Halls lie the Pillars of the West, twenty-one enormous pillars each stand- ing at the entrance of another huge cavern, with each of those caverns holding more idyllic towns and plantations. Beyond the Pillars of the West are the Fourteen States, a barrier zone between the Pillars and Osiris’s realm beyond. The Fourteen States stand in stark contrast to the peaceful realms of the Offer- ing Fields, for they are full of lava flows, mud pits, and demons—servants and guardians of the Pharaonic gods, despite their fearsome natures. Past the Fourteen States lies Fair Ament, a broad valley on the far side of the Mountains of the West. While the caverns under the Mountains are the homes of departed mortal souls and minor godlings (including Imhotep), most of the important deities of the Pharaonic pantheon reside in Fair Ament— including Anubis, Hathor, Isis, Nephthys, Osiris, and Thoth. All these deities spend much time in the Hall of Truth, where they Twelve Hours of Night, and the heavenly arc of the sun’s daylight participate in the judgment of mortal souls. Anubis guides each journey compose Tuat, the otherworld in Pharaonic cosmology. departed soul through the halls under the Mountains of the Although the worshipers of the Pharaonic deities view Tuat as a West to this Hall of Truth. There, the soul is weighed on a bal- single realm of existence, it is actually three distinct Outer Planes ance against the Feather of Ma’at, while the judges consider the where most of the deities of the Pharaonic pantheon reside. dead person’s deeds. Virtuous souls are assigned their eternal
name: The Offering Fields

The Ethereal Plane coexists with the Mate- tight pantheon is Ma’at—the fundamental order of the universe. rial Plane as normal. The Solar Barge sails through the Astral Plane, All the Pharaonic deities (with the exception of the aberrant gods and is visible on the Material Plane as the sun. The Astral Plane also Apep, Set, and Sobek) praise and uphold Ma’at as the order that 137 PANTHEON THE PHARAONIC CHAPTER 5: Pharaonic Cosmology Astral PathoftheSunBarge Pillars of the West Seven Halls House of Truth The Mountains Fourteen of the West Material Fair States Ament The Mt. Manu Offering hereal Fields Shadow Et Twelvehoursofnight underpins their existence and place in the universe. Ma’at is the Re-Horakhty is the son of Isis and Osiris. Previously called principle of truth, justice, law, and order, and without it the uni- Horus, he ascended to take the place of the original sun-god, Re, verse itself would crumble into chaos. after defeating Set to avenge the murder of Osiris. He absorbed the When a mortal dies, Anubis weighs the deceased soul on a scale divine essence of the aging Re, increasing his power beyond that of balanced by the feather of Ma’at. If the soul overbalances the scale, his parents. it is fed to Am-mit, the devourer of souls. If the scale balances, the deceased is revealed as a just and honorable person and finds Dogma reward in the Offering Fields. Re-Horakhty is the god of kings, bestowing his divine blessings Judges invoke the presence of Ma’at so that they may decide the upon the earthly rulers who serve him. Although kings who revere cases before them with justice and impartiality. Rulers strive to Re-Horakhty are fond of preaching about “divine right,” Re- govern according to Ma’at’s principles, often seeking advice from Horakhty demands that monarchs rule wisely and justly, true to clerics, so that justice and order may mark their rule. his lawful good alignment. His divine blessings can be taken away from those who prove themselves unworthy as quickly as they were given.
